newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombia's industrial output down sharply - gov't.
newsitem.headline: Colombia's industrial output down sharply - gov't.

text.p: Colombia's industrial production excluding coffee processing fell 0.59 percent in the first half of 1996 compared with a booming 4.38 percent growth during the first six months of 1995, the National Statistics Department (DANE) said.
Including coffee processing, it said industrial production grew a feeble 0.26 percent compared with 2.34 percent growth in the first half of last year.
Employment in the industrial sector mirrored the sharp slowdown in growth, dropping 2.81 percent during the first half, the DANE said.

It said some of the hardest hit industries included those involved in the production of heavy machinery and electrial appliances, a sector that suffered negative growth of 3.5 percent in the first half.
Producers of crude oil derivatives, including gasoline were hit by 12.92 percent negative growth, while leather tanneries saw their output shrink by 14.08 percent.

DANE gave no reason for the drop in growth, but a closely watched survey released on Tuesday by the National Association of Industrialists (ANDI) cited "insecurity" and violence stemming from Colombia's guerrilla war as the top problem affecting industries across the country.
The survey also cited the political crisis that erupted last year over charges that President Ernesto Samper's 1994 election campaign was partly financed by drug lords.
ANDI's independent survey said industrial production in the first seven months of 1996 had fallen 2.0 percent from the same period last year. -- Tom Brown, Bogota newsroom, 571 610 7944
